One of the most abundant and widespread species in the country.

TaxonEntry.Item: Forewing mostly black from coalesced markings, yellow medial band broken into spots, an isolated orange-brown spot in tornus (connected in congeners), hindwing discal bar greatly reduced below. Female like male, but hindwing discal bar reduced or absent.

TaxonEntry.Item: On Pacific slope at 1100-1500 m; Atlantic slope at 700-1200 m.

This species needs more study to determine if it is a form of P. artena associated with wet habitats (see DeVries 1987) or a distinct species. I have commonly found it to be sympatric with P. artena and consistently different in wing shape and pattern characters at Monteverde.

TaxonEntry.Item: Pacific slope from 700-1500 m; Atlantic slope down to the lowlands.

The amount of black on the hindwing disc is highly variable as is the shape of the yellow spots on the forewing. Unusual in not using Solanaceae as larval hosts. The hosts are vines with clear sap containing pyrrholyzine alkaloids instead of the usual white latex of most family members.

TaxonEntry.Item: Flies low to the ground with shallow wingbeats. Males form small leks in sunny places in understory. Females oviposit on seedlings in light gaps.
Atlantic lowlands, 0-700 m; Poco Sol field station.
Flies low to the ground with shallow wingbeats. Males form small, single-species leks in sunny places in forest understory. Females oviposit on seedlings in light gaps.

TaxonEntry.Item: Tends to be solitary and not join leks of other ithomiines, but two or more males often congregate in open spots in the understory.
Uncommon on upper Pacific slope, more abundant at mid-elevation on Atlantic slope (Refugio Eladio).
The only ithomiine in Costa Rica known to use Gesneriaceae as larval hosts.

TaxonEntry.Item: Strong forewing discal bar, black forewing apex narrow with curved inner edge, postdiscal bar rectangular, veins M2 and M3 black.

TaxonEntry.Item: Atlantic slope from about 400-800 m elevation.
Recorded once at San Gerardo (1100 m) and once near La Tigra (450 m).

Basal third of FW mostly black

TaxonEntry.Item: About same width as adjacent black border

Hind margin of FWD all black

TaxonEntry.Item: Like H. euclea, but translucent; dorsal forewing lacks yellow marginal spots; yellow and black on forewing variable; hindwing discal bar variable.

TaxonEntry.Item: Antennae orange in life, smoky shading in forewing discal cell not reaching vein Cu1, size medium, pattern generally bolder than chiriquensis and klugii but less than olyras, shading on ventral hindwing disc often yellow, pattern darker in female.
Images and text copyright (c) 2001 by William A. Haber, whaber@racsa.co.cr Created: 17 February 2001. Updated: 5 June 2001.

TaxonEntry.Item: Common in the lowlands on both slopes.
One of the most abundant and widespread species in the country.

TaxonEntry.Item: Atlantic slope from lowlands to about 900 m; less abundant toward lowlands. Common at Refugio Eladio and Poco Sol; not reaching San Gerardo.
Sexually dimorphic; female belongs to a different mimicry pattern.

Item.name: FW with translucent smoky black markings
Margin of FWD with line of 4 or more spots

TaxonEntry.Item: Yes (4 or more spots along margin)

Item.name: Basal third of FW mostly black

TaxonEntry.Item: About same width as adjacent black border

Item.name: Costal margin of FWD along discal cell
Hind margin of FWD all black

TaxonEntry.Item: Similar to the male, but hw discal area red-brown not yellow, prominent white marginal spots above, fw more yellow than G. zygia.
Images and text copyright (c) 2001 by William A. Haber, whaber@racsa.co.cr Created: 13 January 2001. Updated: 5 June 2001.

TaxonEntry.Item: Southern pacific region at 0-1000 m reaching as far north as the Central Valley. Not recorded from the Monteverde region.
May be a Pacific slope subspecies of G. zavaleta (DeVries 1987).

Hind margin of FWD all black

TaxonEntry.Item: Similar to male G. zavaleta, but smoky pattern more pronounced, forewing discal cell mostly dark, forewing with much less yellow.
